_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN
NORTHSIDE WASTEWATER TREATMENT PLANT

Executive Summary

The following information is a summary of the Risk Management Plan for chlorine and sulfur dioxide in use at the Northside Wastewater Treatment Plant.  This plan is intended to prevent and minimize the impacts of accidental releases of extremely hazardous substances.  The chlorine and sulfur dioxide inventories exceed the threshold quantities established in the Risk Management Plan Program (RMP) requirements.

The Northside Wastewater Treatment Plant uses chlorine and sulfur dioxide for chlorination and de-chlorination (disinfection) respectfully, of plant effluent.  The use of these chemicals is subject to the provisions of the RMP requirements, due to their A?above-thresholdA? quantities.  


Physical Address:    Northside Wastewater Treatment Plant
       S 1/2 of SE 1/4 of Section 6,
Township 20 North, Range 14 East of I.M., in Tulsa County, State of Oklahoma
       Latitude:    36A?-14'-20"N
            Longitude:    95A?-51'-15"W


Mailing Address:    Northside Wastewater Treatment Plant
       5665 N. 105th E. Avenue
       Tulsa, OK. 74117
       
       
       
This plan follows the EPA Risk Management Program guidelines and includes the following elements:

Hazard Assessment
Worst Case Scenario
Alternative Release Analysis

Prevention Program Three
Management System
Employee Participation Plan
Process Safety Information
Process Hazard Analysis
Operating Procedure
Training
Contractor Safety
Pre-startup Review
Mechanical Integrity
Hot Work Permit
Management of Change
Incident Investigation
Emergency Planning and Response
Compliance Audits




Five-Year Accident History
On November 26, 2007 at approximately 3:35pm the operations department responded to an alarm from the safety detection system in the chlorine storage area.  In the course of finding the leak, it was determined that the fuse plug was leaking because the cylinder was inadvertently over-pressurized.  During the investigation of the leak, o

ne operator was taken to the emergency room for precautionary measures.  He was cleared to come back to work with no adverse effects and has had no problems since.  The cylinder of chlorine was worked on for 22 hours and 10 minutes by the City of Tulsa Hazmat Team and Brenntag (chemical supplier).  The release was estimated to be 8.4 lbs.  There were no on-site or off-site impacts.  There were no process changes that resulted from the release.  However, retraining on current operation procedures was completed and updates are being made to the Emergency Action Plan.  Meetings were held with the City of Tulsa Hazmat Team and Brenntag about future response planning.

The Emergency Response Plan
The purpose of this procedure is to ensure that the Northside Wastewater Treatment Plant maintains up-to-date and complete written emergency action plans (EAPs) and effective response capabilities for all covered processes.  Comprehensive emergency action plans, when combined with emergency response training and drills, can effectively minimize the impact of an accidental release by ensuring proper and quick facility response.  A summary of the requirements as outlined in this section is as follows:

* This facility shall investigate each incident that resulted in, or could reasonably have resulted in a catastrophic release.
* This investigation shall be initiated promptly, no later than 48 hours following the incident.
* The guidelines and reports included herein shall be followed for each incident.    
* All affected personnel whose job tasks are affected by the findings shall review the findings.
* Investigation summaries shall be retained for five years.

Planned Changes
A study is being conducted to evaluate alternatives to the chlorine and sulfur dioxide gas disinfection systems currently in use at the Northside Wastewater Treatment Plant.
